verses.text: Can you draw out Leviathan with a hook, or tie down his tongue with a rope?
verses.comment: Leviathan is a symbol of chaos and evil in the world. God’s rhetorical question highlights humanity's inability to control ultimate evil or chaos on its own. Early interpreters saw Leviathan as both a real sea creature and a representation of spiritual powers (see Isaiah 27:1 for further spiritual interpretation).

verses.text: Can you put a rope through his nose or pierce his jaw with a hook?
verses.comment: These images imply dominion and control. The inability of man to subdue Leviathan points towards humanity's need for a savior and mediator.

verses.text: Will he plead with you for mercy, or speak gentle words to you?
verses.comment: Leviathan is not subject to mankind, nor can he be reasoned with as a peer. This highlights the transcendence needed to overcome evil.

verses.text: Will he make a covenant with you to take him as your servant forever?
verses.comment: The inability to make a covenant with Leviathan contrasts with how God makes covenants with humanity. True peace and order come only through God’s initiative.

verses.text: Will you play with him like a bird, or tie him on a leash for your girls?
verses.comment: God’s sarcasm reveals that what man subdues is trivial compared to Leviathan. This points to humanity’s limitations in the face of spiritual realities.

verses.text: Will traders bargain over him? Will they divide him among the merchants?
verses.comment: Unlike ordinary animals, Leviathan cannot be bought or sold, laying groundwork for understanding a power beyond economic reach. Echoes of Christ’s uniqueness emerge here (see Isa. 52:3).

verses.text: Can you fill his skin with harpoons, or his head with fishing spears?
verses.comment: No ordinary weapon can harm Leviathan. In tradition, this foreshadows divine victory over evil (cf. Ps 74:14).

verses.text: Lay your hand on him; remember the battle—you will not do it again!
verses.comment: Those who attempt to contend with chaos unprepared suffer loss. This verse upholds the need for humble reliance on God’s strength.

verses.text: Behold, the hope of overcoming him is false. Even the sight of him overwhelms.
verses.comment: Only God inspires both rightful fear and hope. Ultimate defeat of evil is outside human capacity.

verses.text: No one is so fierce as to dare to stir him up. Who then is able to stand before Me?
verses.comment: Here God's challenge shifts toward divine authority. This establishes the uniquely reverential position of worship owed to the Lord. Spiritual and liturgical implications can be drawn.

verses.text: Who has given to Me that I should repay him? Whatever is under the whole heaven is Mine.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is emphasized. This has implications for stewardship and obedience, foreshadowing teachings on surrender in the New Testament.

verses.text: I will not keep silent concerning his limbs, or his mighty strength, or the graceful form of his body.
verses.comment: God details Leviathan’s form, emphasizing the mystery and awe of creation—an echo of the transcendence we encounter in prayer and worship.

verses.text: Who can strip off his outer garment? Who can come within his double armor?
verses.comment: Leviathan’s impenetrable protection points to mysteries hidden from fallen man, referencing clothing imagery connected with Adam and Eve.

verses.text: Who can open the doors of his face? Around his teeth is terror.
verses.comment: The terror inspired by Leviathan’s mouth evokes awe and dread that only God can dispel. This image recalls the power of words and their consequences throughout Scripture.

verses.text: His back is made of rows of shields, tightly sealed together.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s armor is a metaphor for invincibility, foreshadowing the spiritual armor referenced in the New Testament.

verses.text: One is so near to another that no air can come between them.
verses.comment: The perfect seal in Leviathan’s armor points to invulnerability, a quality only God can challenge.

verses.text: They are joined one to another; they hold fast and cannot be separated.
verses.comment: Perfect unity is rare in nature—here symbolizing a deeper spiritual reality. The spiritual unity of the faithful is foreshadowed.

verses.text: His sneezing flashes forth light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the dawn.
verses.comment: Imagery of light foreshadows Christ, the true light of the world (see John 8:12).

verses.text: Out of his mouth go flaming torches; sparks of fire shoot out.
verses.comment: The mouth as the source of fire may correspond to prophetic judgment and is symbolic of powers that can only be subdued by God.

verses.text: Out of his nostrils comes smoke, as from a boiling pot or a burning rushes.
verses.comment: Imagery akin to Sinai’s smoke at God’s presence—invoking worship and awe.

verses.text: His breath sets coals ablaze, and flames come out of his mouth.
verses.comment: Destructive breath versus the purifying fire from Isaiah’s vision; foreshadows the difference between the holy and the profane.

verses.text: In his neck burns strength, and terror dances before him.
verses.comment: Strength and terror combine in Leviathan, but in God strength is perfectly ordered toward justice.

verses.text: The folds of his flesh stick together, firm on him and immovable.
verses.comment: Emphasis on stability and firmness, in contrast to humanity’s frailty and need for spiritual fortitude.

verses.text: His heart is hard as stone, as hard as the lower millstone.
verses.comment: A hard heart symbolizes spiritual resistance. The recurring call in Scripture is for hearts to be made new (cf. Ezekiel 36:26).

verses.text: When he rises up, the mighty are afraid; at the crashing they are beside themselves.
verses.comment: True power belongs to God alone; earthly power is often shaken in the face of true spiritual realities.

verses.text: Though the sword reaches him, it does not avail, nor the spear, dart, or javelin.
verses.comment: Physical weapons fail. This prefigures the spiritual weapons given by God to the faithful, as in Ephesians 6:11-17.

verses.text: He counts iron as straw, and bronze as rotten wood.
verses.comment: Worldly strength is easily dismissed. Only spiritual strength, rooted in God, endures.

verses.text: The arrow cannot make him flee. Slingstones are turned into stubble by him.
verses.comment: Inefficacy of earthly weapons points to the need for faith and divine means to overcome evil.

verses.text: Clubs are counted as stubble; he laughs at the rattling of the javelin.
verses.comment: Derision at human strength alludes to the necessity of surrendering to God’s will and trusting His power.

verses.text: His underparts are like sharp potsherds; he spreads himself like a threshing sledge on the mire.
verses.comment: The dangerous nature of Leviathan in every part shows the totality of evil and chaos. Only God can redeem creation from such corruption.

verses.text: He makes the deep boil like a pot; he makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s disturbance over the sea is reminiscent of cosmic upheaval, paralleled in apocalyptic visions.

verses.text: Behind him he leaves a shining wake; one would think the deep to be white-haired.
verses.comment: His path changes the very appearance of creation—a shadow of how sin mars the world, and underlines the need for redemption.

verses.text: On earth there is nothing like him, one made without fear.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s uniqueness invites comparison to Christ as the ultimate answer to evil’s singular challenge.

verses.text: He sees everything that is high; he is king over all the sons of pride.
verses.comment: Leviathan as king of pride prefigures the adversary defeated by Christ. The victory over this enemy is fully revealed in the gospel, where humility, faith, and sacramental grace are the keys to overcoming pride and evil.
